content.description:
Â I had a fly fisherman ask me why I had my pool table on my back last time I biked the Creeper (referring to my crashpad of course)

 When you walk up to the boulder, the first side you will approach is the side you climb. the slightly angled, pointy topped side.

 Stand start, left hand on the face on a good crimp, right hand on the arete in a edgy two/three finger pocket.

 Gain feet (heel hook low to the right). Climb directly over the point using smaller holds. top out over arete top.

 There could be a hard sit start to this line for sure...
content.protection: pads. the landing could be pretty sketch if not confidant on the grade.
content.location: the first side you will approach is the side you climb. the slightly angled, pointy topped side.

content.description:
A perfectly picturesque riverside boulder. 

 As you ride down the trail, you will come to Trestle #40. If you want to check out the boulder before deciding whether or not to go to it, ride across 40 and look across the creek. this is the larger boulder wit the slightly overhung, pointy top.

 There could still be a sit start to the stand I did, and possibly a short/mantle line as well.

 More or less this is just a fantastic photo stop. The problem wouldn't be very good if the setting weren't amazing.
